item.title: Asians struggle with their comfort levels when it comes to using air conditioning
item.description: A Hong Kong-based startup, Ambi Labs, has initiated a crowdsourcing campaign for their latest product, Ambi Climate. This innovative device is designed to optimize air conditioning systems based on two years of user feedback gathered from ten Asian markets. Source: Ambi Labs. Ambi Labs conducted extensive online surveys across ten major Asian markets, engaging with over 4,000 participants. The findings revealed that the most significant challenge with air conditioners lies in maintaining a comfortable room temperature.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Exchanging the Electrolytic Capacitors, the RPM Relay, and Adjusting the Motor Signal
item.description: My work on the Beogram 4000 turntable restoration continued with replacing all the electrolytic capacitors on the main board and power supply. I used high-quality, long-lasting Japanese components rated at 105C. Knowing that the RPM relays in these models can fail over time, I decided to swap out the old relay with a new one for improved long-term reliability. My objective is to restore these vintage turntables to like-new condition, both aesthetically and functionally.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Adjusting the Chassis Springs and the Platter Height
item.description: The Beogram 4000 restoration is progressing into the final cosmetic stage. With the turntable functioning correctly, the focus is now on refining the exterior and replacing minor parts like the plug. Currently, I am fine-tuning the platter height, tilt, and the leaf springs supporting the turntable’s floating chassis. This is a delicate process with many interconnected factors. The sensor arm’s alignment, platter angle, transport lock travel, and belt tension all need to be perfect for the platter to be level, centered, and parallel to the arms, all while ensuring the chassis clears the open locks.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of AC Motor
item.description: I noticed a knocking sound coming from my Beogram 4000’s AC motor, which meant the Oilite brass bearing needed lubrication. These bearings are designed to release oil onto the motor shaft over time. Eventually, they need to be replaced or re-lubricated. item.title: Beogram 4002 (5501): Repair of 'Knocking' AC Motor
item.description: I prefer to thoroughly test restored Beograms to ensure they’re free of intermittent issues. It’s not uncommon for new problems to appear with regular use. This was the case with a recently restored AC motor Beogram 4002 (5501). After playing a few records, I detected a faint knocking sound coming from inside the turntable. Upon removing the aluminum plates, I discovered the knocking synchronized with the AC motor’s rotation. Adjusting the motor tilt provided temporary noise reduction, but the knocking always returned, intensifying with each record played until it was noticeable during quieter tracksâ€”an unacceptable issue for a turntable!

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration and Adjustment of AC Platter Motor
item.description: After restoring the electronics of a Beogram 4000 turntable, attention turned to the AC platter motor. This model features an older pulley design without built-in belt guards, relying instead on separate guards added to the motor mounting posts. These added guards are not essential, as the pulley’s shape effectively secures the belt. Motor tilt allows for adjustments to the belt’s vertical positioning. Like the DC motors in later Beogram models, the AC motors can also suffer from dried-out bearings.
